 yodeled...well maybe once in the shower...but I think Stefan lives closer =
to yodel country...let's ask him.=A0 O-de-layhe-hoo.=A0=A0 Ron

Hi steve=A0=A0 Not sure =
about the concept.=A0 Will you be=A0playing=A0the five tones and then await=
ing and hopefully recording=A0morse code responses?=A0 Or will you be sendi=
ng out a question in morse code=A0and listening for a morse code answer?=A0=
 With the great success rate=A0some of you have=A0I think you could yodel a=
nd get something back...maybe morse code=A0will work.=A0 Yodelling... now t=
here's and idea.=A0=A0 lol=A0=A0 Ron


----- Original Message ----
From: St=
eve Hultay <urkel23@aol. com>

Sent: Saturday, =
April 19, 2008 10:30:42 AM
Subject: [EVP-ITC] New Test---Morse Code




I'm=
 going to have to run this one past my father, being he is a Ham 
Operator =
(KA2RHU) in NJ for anyone who wants to know. I took 5 files 
and played the=
m in a sequence and recorded it, it consists of tone 
frequencies ranging f=
rom 100hz, 250hz, 440hz, 1khz and 10khz. They 
were 5 second clips of each =
and than i ran it through EvpMaker and it 
sounds like morse code, but i ha=
ve to brush up on it to see if it makes 
any sense. Is it possible for them=
 to communicate through morse code? 
I've attached a 30 second clip of the =
example running it through 
EvpMaker. I'll also attach my original tone fil=
e i created.

-Steve H.

<DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">Who's gonna be the first to volunteer to record themselves yodeling for us?  Maybe you can Ron, since it was your idea.  Haa!<BR><BR>Jeremy<BR><BR>
<DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">----- Original Message ----<BR>From: Ron Lederer <ronriko@yahoo. com><BR>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com<BR>Sent: Saturday, April 19, 2008 12:31:07 PM<BR>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] New Test---Morse Code<BR><BR>
<DIV id=ygrp-text>
<P></P>
<DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">
<DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">Hi steve   Not sure about the concept.  Will you be playing the five tones and then awaiting and hopefully recording morse code responses?  Or will you be sending out a question in morse code and listening for a morse code answer?  With the great success rate some of you have I think you could yodel and get something back...maybe morse code will work.  Yodelling... now there's and idea.   lol   Ron<BR><BR>
<DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">----- Original Message ----<BR>From: Steve Hultay <urkel23@aol. com><BR>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com<BR>Sent: Saturday, April 19, 2008 10:30:42 AM<BR>Subject: [EVP-ITC] New Test---Morse Code<BR><BR>
<DIV id=ygrp-text>
<P><BR><BR>I'm going to have to run this one past my father, being he is a Ham <BR>Operator (KA2RHU) in NJ for anyone who wants to know. I took 5 files <BR>and played them in a sequence and recorded it, it consists of tone <BR>frequencies ranging from 100hz, 250hz, 440hz, 1khz and 10khz. They <BR>were 5 second clips of each and than i ran it through EvpMaker and it <BR>sounds like morse code, but i have to brush up on it to see if it makes <BR>any sense. Is it possible for them to communicate through morse code? <BR>I've attached a 30 second clip of the example running it through <BR>EvpMaker. I'll also attach my original tone file i created.<BR><BR>-Steve H.<BR><BR></P></DIV></DIV></DIV></DIV><BR>
